text:
```julia> using STREAMBenchmark
[ Info: Precompiling STREAMBenchmark [05e9033e-e298-417a-adae-495536c11ad4]

julia> memory_bandwidth(verbose=true)
COPY:  74593.8 MB/s
SCALE: 75572.1 MB/s
ADD:   75428.4 MB/s
TRIAD: 75899.1 MB/s
(75500.3, 74593.8, 75899.1)

julia> STREAMBenchmark.multithreading() = false

julia> memory_bandwidth(verbose=true)
COPY:  25702.9 MB/s
SCALE: 26215.1 MB/s
ADD:   24204.0 MB/s
TRIAD: 23823.8 MB/s
(24953.4, 23823.8, 26215.1)

julia> versioninfo()
Julia Version 1.7.0-DEV.762
Commit 6a30cc5635* (2021-03-27 07:36 UTC)
Platform Info:
  OS: Linux (x86_64-generic-linux)
  CPU: Intel(R) Core(TM) i9-10980XE CPU @ 3.00GHz
  WORD_SIZE: 64
  LIBM: libopenlibm
  LLVM: libLLVM-11.0.1 (ORCJIT, cascadelake)
Environment:
  JULIA_EXCLUSIVE = 1
  JULIA_NUM_THREADS = 36```

text:
```julia> memory_bandwidth(verbose=true)
COPY:  75322.4 MB/s
SCALE: 78412.6 MB/s
ADD:   75942.6 MB/s
TRIAD: 77458.7 MB/s
(76700.7, 75322.4, 78412.6)

julia> Threads.nthreads()
18```
Results were a little better with 18 instead of 36 threads.

text: I can confirm that (watching htop), only cores 1-18 showed any activity, with core 1 being the primary.

elements.text: I can confirm that (watching htop), only cores 1-18 showed any activity, with core 1 being the primary.

text:
Oh, and:
```julia> STREAMBenchmark.avxt() = true

julia> memory_bandwidth(verbose=true)
COPY:  78182.0 MB/s
SCALE: 80731.8 MB/s
ADD:   79484.3 MB/s
TRIAD: 79585.3 MB/s
(79534.8, 78182.0, 80731.8)```

elements.text:

julia> memory_bandwidth(verbose=true)
COPY:  78182.0 MB/s
SCALE: 80731.8 MB/s
ADD:   79484.3 MB/s
TRIAD: 79585.3 MB/s
(79534.8, 78182.0, 80731.8)

text: Oh your `avtx = true` results look consistent across kernels. For me I saw two different plateaus, one for COPY and SCALE, the other one for ADD and TRIAD.

elements.text: results look consistent across kernels. For me I saw two different plateaus, one for COPY and SCALE, the other one for ADD and TRIAD.

text: BTW: <https://discourse.julialang.org/t/thread-affinitization-pinning-julia-threads-to-cores/58069>

attachments.title: Thread affinitization: pinning Julia threads to cores
attachments.text: Hi all, as part of my attempt to create a simple port of the STREAM benchmark (STREAMBenchmark.jl) for estimating the memory bandwidth of a machine I asked myself whether it is possible to pin Julia threads to specific cores. I’m mostly focused on linux but macOS would be great as well (though I doubt it is possible on the latter). (I know that I can pin tasks to thread using, for example, @tspawnat 4 Threads.threadid() from ThreadPools.jl. Here I am concerned about pinning threads to cores.) ...
attachments.fallback: JuliaLang: Thread affinitization: pinning Julia threads to cores

text:
Hmm, you could file an issue. Are you on the latest version?
How different were the plateaus?

elements.text:

text: I used `JULIA_EXCLUSIVE=1` for these benchmarks.
It basically pins to cores `1:Threads.nthreads()`
so with `-t8`, Julia is on cores 1-8

```julia> memory_bandwidth(verbose=true)
COPY:  29998.7 MB/s
SCALE: 29788.9 MB/s
ADD:   28905.1 MB/s
TRIAD: 29392.9 MB/s
(29590.9, 28905.1, 29998.7)

julia> STREAMBenchmark.avxt() = true

julia> memory_bandwidth(verbose=true)
COPY:  27450.4 MB/s
SCALE: 27237.5 MB/s
ADD:   23167.6 MB/s
TRIAD: 23932.2 MB/s
(25584.9, 23167.6, 27450.4)```
